Any listings that are inappropriate or do not comply with our rules will be removed.”

title: poo donors faecal transplants donation banks
story: The procedure is used to treat a debilitating gut condition known as clostridium dficile, a bacterial infection which attacks the colon.Scientists claim the disease can effectively be cured within days of a single faecal matter transplanttreatment.Its something which has taken off in Australia - where healthcare is private - with poo clinics popping up across the country.Some even operate was poo banks, where people with healthy guts can donate their faeces to help others.But experts say the demand for the treatment has actually led to a stool shortage.Professor Thomas Barody, who runs the Centre for Digestive Health in Sydney, told news.au that poo banks need more healthy stool supplies.Potential donors are screened, with about  in  found to be viable and able to become regular contributors at the poo bank.Donations can be dropped off at the centre and the stool is then used either in a direct transplant via an enema in the anus, or turned into a pill form - which Prof Barody refers as “crapsules”.At the moment, its only been been used to treat clostridium dficile-associated disease .The bacterial condition that occurs in the gut and causes a disturbance in normal bacteria, allowing a dangerous organism to flourish.Associate Professor Andrew Holmes, a microbiology expert at The University of Sydney, said: “Effective cure can be seen within one to two days of a single FMT treatment, and it seldom requires more than three treatments.But experts say the medical community is starting to latch onto FMT and research into the role of gut bacteria in other conditions is expanding.Dr Sudarshan Paramsothy, a gastroenterologist and researcher at The University of Sydney, said: “We’re learning that gut bacteria is implicated with a lot of conditions — not only gastrointestinal but others like obesity, cardiovascular disease, autism, liver disease and psychiatric issues.“Whenis disturbed, it can have quite profound affects that are beyond what one might simply expect.”While the treatment holds enormous promise for sufferers of untreatable gut conditions, experts warn the hype surrounding FMT’s potential use in other areas of medicine is yet to match the science.Dr Paramsothy continued: “None ofare at a stage where there have been signicant studies showing benefit. We’re very early in the research phase.It is only used when other treatments, such as long-term antibiotics, have failed.How is it performed The treatment should only ever be performed by a qualied doctor.It involves collecting a stool sample from a donor, who is tested to ensure they carry no harmful bugs and have the correct bacteria in their digestive tracts to help combat the bug.The sample is then mixed with saline, strained and placed into the patient via a colonoscopy, endoscopy or an enema.How does it work FMT aims to replace good bacteria that has been killed or suppressed, often by the use of antibiotics.This killing of good bacteria allows bad bacteria, specically C.df, to over-populate the colon.The infection can then lead to a condition called C.df colitis, which causes painful and sometimes fatal diarrhoea.By restoring the balance of bacteria in the intestines, the idea is that the patient will be better able to fight infection.Who can be a donor Donors can be family members, or others who are known to you.But, they must:Donors are screened for a range of infectious diseases, including HIV, hepatitis A, B and C and syphilis.Source: Guy’s and St Thomas’ HospitalIn April, a University of Arizona study created shockwaves after researchers demonstrated long-term benefits of faecal transplants in reducing autism symptoms in children.A growing number of scientists believe gut microbiomes affect how the brain communicates with the body as well as general neurological health.The study, published in the journal Scientic Reports, found a special type of faecal transplant improved gut health and eased autism symptoms.The study said: “At two years post-treatment, most of the initial improvements in gut symptoms remained. In addition, parents reported a slow steady reduction of ASD symptoms during treatment and over the next two years.“A professional evaluator found a  per cent reduction in core ASD symptomsat two years post-treatment compared to before treatment began.”While the results are promising on the surface, Dr Paramsothy says it’s “early days” when it comes to scientically demonstrating the broader benefits of FMT.He said: “Developments like these are always promising, but what you really want to be seeing is randomised control trial data.“It’s important that we get confirmatory studies that demonstrate true benefit before we start advocating it as a main line treatment. There’s a lot of work still to do.”An American man who had a faecal transplant claimed it saved his le after he contracted an infection following an operation to remove his wisdom teeth.Meanwhile, theres been a rising trend for DIY poo transplants - but experts say they could put peoples health at risk.

title: royal ascot racegoers day two latest
story: Glamorous celebs were safely tucked away in their VIP boxes as they cheered on the horses during the downpour that left thousands of average spectators scurrying for their umbrellas. Women, who had donned spectacular hats and elaborate fascinators for the highlight of the Royal calendar, desperately tried to save their dresses from the rain with plastic ponchos while men were seen striding through the rain this afternoon.Celebs including Liam Payne, Helen Flanagan and Debbie McGee pulled out all the stops in the fashion stakes, while Good Morning Britain host Piers Morgan posed cheerfully with fellow presenter Susanna Reid and Joan Collins.But all didnt seem to be going too well for GMB presenter Piers, who appeared red faced as his horse thundered down the track.Jason Manford also made an appearance, along with TV presenters Francesca Cumani and Charlotte Hawkins.And Emmerdale star Angela Grfin could be seen cheering on her horse as the second day of the annual event unfolded this afternoon.The Queen joined the posh crowds this afternoon, undoubtedly hoping one of her two horses might win in the races today.The -year-old has two horses - Elector, trained by Sir Michael Stoute, and Seniority, trained by William Haggas - racing in the prestigious five-day event.She yesterday spent the first day of the famous meet with her family but will surely be keen to watch the races this afternoon.Her first Royal Ascot victory was in the Royal Hunt Cup won by her horse Choir Boy in , while her last was three years ago when Dartmouth triumphed in the Hardwicke Stakes - the monarchs rd winner at the event.Thoroughbreds are the Queens great passion, and she is probably never happier when working with John Warren, her bloodstock and racing adviser.Her love of all things equine began as a little girl, and she went on to breed her own horses and enjoys the thrill of seeing them race.She is a respected figure in the racing world and her horses have won four out of the five flat racing classics - the , Guineas and , Guineas, the Oaks and the St Leger - with only the Derby eluding her.The Queen made sporting history in  when she became the first reigning monarch to win Royal Ascots Gold Cup.And she has attended every day of the meeting for the past  years and the last time she missed a moment of the event being her own coronation in .She is even said to read the Racing Post every morning.THE QUEEN is a keen racegoer and will attend Royal Ascot every day of the royal meeting . She often seems at her happiest while at the races, and will no doubt be keeping an eye on her own horses as they try and romp to victory.Her horses going for gold this year include:Kate Middleton and Zara Tindall were yesterday pictured roaring with laughter as they headed to the first day of the Royal Ascot.And she was told to pay attention by Camilla at St Georges Chapel in Windsor yesterday.It comes just a few weeks after fans became convinced Prince Harry told Meghan Markle to turn around during Trooping the Colour on the Buckingham Palace balcony.Punters typically bet on the colour the Queens hat, as bookies from William Hill ly backed the colour pink - her Majesty arrived wearing pale blue.And leading bookmaker Coral now makes it just evensthat the Queen wears a pink hat on Day Two of Royal Ascot as punters get their bets on for a second day running.Yesterday Coral customers were cheering after the Queen wore blue, which had been backed into favourite.Corals Harry Aitkenhead said: It was joy for punters yesterday as they correctly predicted that the Queen would wear blue and they are back for more today. This time everybody is convinced itll be pink and weve been forced to slash the odds to just evens as the bets mount up.Her Majesty and the rest of the Royal Procession arrived at pm sharp before racing each day, half an hour prior to the first race.The carriages leave Windsor Castle earlier in the afternoon and enter the racecourse through the golden gates before they pass the thousands of well-wishers in front of the grandstand.The procession is a timeless tradition unique to Royal Ascot which dates all the way back to .

title: property house pembroke cottage hidden basement
story: From the outside Conway in Pembroke Dock appears to be a pretty little cottage but looks are certainly deceptive when it comes to this £, property which is currently up for sale.Anyone stumping up the cash though will have their work cut out as even the estate agent Guy Thomas  Co admits it is in need of a complete renovation.The front door opens on to the lounge which comes with a large picture window and passing along the staircase, which comes with a cloakroom, there’s the sizeable kitchen that runs along the back of the house.A partition wall separates the kitchen area off from the dining roomGoing up the stairs there are two bedrooms in the loft which come with vaulted ceilings and feature beams.The front bedroom features a stained glass window while the back one enjoys panoramic views overlooking the River Cleddau estuary.If that wasn’t enough each bedroom has its own store room and there’s a third one also on the first floor for even more storage space.But that’s not all as the seemingly small cottage contains a secret.Just opposite the front door is another set of stairs but instead of going up to the bedrooms, these go down.They lead to a large basement room that covers the whole floor space of the property which could be used for a iety of s.The basement also has a full-sized bathroom in the corner so could possibly be turned into a large master bedroom or even a study or workspace.

title: paul crossley tube pusher crack addict pet shop boys
story: Paul Crossley, , shoved -year-old Sir Robert Malpas onto the rails at Marble Arch station in central London on April  last year.A court heard how Crossley had gone to Londons West End after having the Pet Shop Boys song West End Girls in his head and believed it contained a message for him.The hit song from the pop duo contains the lyrics: You think youre mad too unstable [...] Call the police theres a mad man around, Running down underground.Crossley told cops afterwards hed had no sleep after taking £ worth of crack the previous day.Sir Robert, who attended the sentencing hearing at the Old Bailey, was saved by teacher Riyah El Hussani who leapt from the  just one minute before a train was due to arrive.Five psychiatric reports by three doctors were filed on paranoid schizophrenic Crossley after he was found guilty of two counts of attempted murder by a jury.The second count was for trying to push a second man, Tobias French, on to the tracks at Tottenham Court Road as a train approached.Crossley boarded the train before then attacking Sir Robert at nearby Marble Arch station.The court heard how Crossley had pushed Sir Robert deliberately because he looked odd and looked unlikely to be able to withstand the attack.Judge Nicholas Hilliard QC said: As far as Sir Robert Malpas is concerned, apart from lacerations to his skull, he had multiple fractures to his right pelvis, and spent a week in hospital.The recovery was long and he described the effect on his le as huge, emotionally and physically.Referring to Dr Hannah John-Kamens three reports on Crossley, he said: An amount of stress has been placed on this defendant hearing a song, West End Girls, and getting on the Tube.The defendant said in evidence that before pushing... something in his head say, yes, yes, yes, I am going to harm someone one.We know that the defendant had in fact been threatened by drug dealers to whom he owed a large sum of money.It may be fair to say that in the first report a number of possible factors are mentioned, come the end shes probably putting psychosis up to the top of the list in terms of signicance where as Dr Joseph takes a dferent view.The court heard Crossley was given a -month suspended jail sentence last January for sexually assaulting a care worker in June  and racially abusing another female care worker for saying he should go to his probation service appointments.Crossley, of Leyton, East London, also received a two months suspended jail sentence for having a kne in a public place in September .Benjamin Aina QC, prosecuting, said: He pushed Tobias French towards the train tracks as a Central Line train was approaching.The train was about  metres away.Mr French was fortunate in that he was able to resist.Mr Crossley then caught a train to Marble Arch station where he pushed Sir Robert Malpas on to the train tracks.The court heard Sir Robert was  years old at the time and suffered severe cuts to his head, needing  stitches, as well as a fractured pelvis.Mr Aina said: While Sir Robert was in the pit below the tracks he was bravely assisted by a member of the public, Riyah El Hussani, who jumped down to the tracks.Mr El Hussani received a burn as he touched an electried track, but again, fortunately, he has recovered from his physical injury.When asked for an explanation for his action by police in his formal interview held the next day, Mr Crossley simply said, I had no sleep.During the trial, he stated in evidence, he was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia when he was  year old.The defendant claimed he had not taken medication for his condition that day and had taken about £ worth of crack cocaine the day before.Continuing to describe his claims, Mr Aina said: It was a day out in West End when he was on the train  he began to hear voices and was paranoid, he said he pushed Mr French to scare him.When he got to Marble Arch he was having a panic attack.He said he was only intending to push Sir Robert Malpas to the floor.Giving evidence Dr Anneka John-Kamen said psyhcosis was a key actor in his actions when asked by Mr AIna.She said he had attributed signicant meaning to hearing the West End Girls song in the West End.He does have a history of hearing things on the radio or television which he gives signicant meaning to.She said these delusions of reference were an element of psychosis.The sentencing hearing continues.

title: world is more peaceful now than 2014
story: The world is now more peaceful than it has ever been in  the last  years, with an improvement score of . per average country.The Global Peace Index measures the world’s most and least peaceful countries against  dferent criteria, including violent crimes, financial contributions to UN peacekeeping missions, political terror, number of refugees and access to small arms and light weapons.The countrys scores are tallied up with a higher score being less peaceful, and a lower score being more peaceful.According to the findings, Iceland continues its  year reign as the world’s ‘most peaceful country’ scoring just . on the peace-measuring scale.The United Kingdom ranked at  on the list, with a score of ., up five places from last year. Overall the UK was rated high for peace.The most peaceful score for the United Kingdom came from Ongoing Domestic and International Conflict, with just ..The UKs least peaceful score was in Militarisation Domain, coming in at . with the highest score in that area being Afghanistans ..According to this year’s GPI, Afghanistan has overtaken Syria to covet the title of the world’s ‘least peaceful country’ following ISIS’ loss of its last remaining territory in Syria earlier this year.The Middle East and North Africa remains the worlds least peaceful region, with no country  from the region breaking into the top .Afghanistan was followed by Syria, South Sudan Yemen and Iraq to complete the worlds top  most dangerous countries, with all experiencing ongoing conflicts.However, the region enjoyed marginal improvement in comparison to the previous year.Europe remains the most peaceful region in the world, recording a slight improvement in peacefulness in  after several years of deterioration, according to the report.Resurgent nationalism and terrorism are currently Europes biggest threats to peace.Despite global improvements, world peace has deteriorated by . per cent since .Figures from the GPI show that while countries are improving their peacefulness gradually, deterioration is larger than improvement on the whole.Overall, world peace has deteriorated for eight of the  years that the Global Index of Peace has been recording levels of peacefulness.On the whole, the GPI claims More people across the world now feel that they have more freedom in le, are more satisfied with le, and are treated with more respect than in .Many more people also feel that their countries are better places to live for ethnic and religious minorities.

title: mediterranean cat fox dog teeth bushy tail discovered myth
story: For years the mysterious creature has been rumoured to be roaming the Asco Forest in Corsica.But its discovery could be a new species, currently unknown to scientists.The large cat has a bushy, ringed tail, a russet coloured belly and short whiskers, referred to in generations of Corsican shepherd mythology.In , the first known cat-fox became trapped in a chicken coop, and since then scientists have been studying the felines population.It has been named Ghjattu volpe.The cat-fox shares some features with domestic felines, but its dferences include wider ears, shorter whiskers, highly developed canine teeth and a bushy tail with two - four rings and a black tip, plus stripes on its front legs and a russet-coloured belly.Measuring at a whopping  inches from head to tail, an adult cat-fox has a dense silky coat that repels ticks, lice and fleas.Pierre Benedetti, chief environmental technician of the National Hunting and Wildle Office who has been researching the cats for over a decade, told the AFP: Its a wonderful discovery.Its their size and their tail that earned them the name cat-fox across the island.We believe that its a wild natural species which was known, but not scientically identied, because its an extremely inconspicuous animal with nocturnal habits.Mr Benedetti added that researchers were unable to make contact with the mythological creature until one was caught unexpectedly in  in a chicken coop and Olcanis in Cap Corse.The mythology was passed down from generation to generation.The big-toothed animal has been dubbed Ghjattu volpe in Corsican.The creatures were rumoured to stalk the Asco forest in the islands north.Their nocturnal habits and inconspicuous nature had hidden them from researchers.However, one was accidentally caught in a chicken coop in .The cats are large, measuring around  inches long.The first cat-fox was captured in  using advanced photography followed by physical traps.

title: couple norfolk home tilts nightmare
story: Ken Pitts and we Gail are currently unable to live in their idyllic thatched home on the Norfolk Broads after it started sinking three months ago.Their neighbours believe the s-built cottage started descending shortly after it was re-thatched due to wooden pile foundations breaking under its weight.But today owner Ken said there had been no warning signs that the west side of their home starting to dip - and that it simply happened overnight, leaving them devastated.The sight of their topsy-turvy home has caused quite  a stir among locals in Horning as signs were put up warning of Danger and Unsafe.Local Maggie Tuck wrote on Facebook: I heard one end was steel piles the other was old wooden piles. Its the wood piles that have collapsed.They are going to take off the thatch to save it and then demolish. Very sad.Sally Blackburn added: We passed this last week and I actually couldnt bear to look at it, too upsetting!Viv Garner wrote: I used to dream of living there when I was a child. So sad to see this.The three-bedroom house boasts a large garden looking onto the River Bure, as well boat mooring and fishing opportunities.It also includes a master with king-sized bed and balcony, a well-equipped kitchen and a light and airy sitting room leading out onto a large riverside sundeck.Over the last five years  properties have been sold on the road in the village which has shops, pubs and restaurants.A Broads Authority spokesperson said: It is a huge shame that this lovely cottage appears to be in such a precarious position.Unfortunately it is something that can be an ongoing danger for properties built on unstable ground.We wish the owners all the best as they assess what can be done.If the cottage is within our area as a planning authority we would offer free pre-planning advice should this be needed in the future.The owners said they are working with their insurers to try and find a resolution, and did not wish to comment further.

title: gangster job notorious face tattoo
story: Puk Kireka, who has been in prison twice, has set up a crowdfunding page to pay for his college fees to become a personal trainer.The dad-of-three joined the Mongrel Mob - one of New Zealands most feared biker gangs in  and has been mocked by rapper  Cent for his face tat.The tattooed kiwi claims he has turned his le around, battled his meth addiction and now plays rugby for Tamatea in Napier but says hes still struggling to get a job.The crowdfunding page, Give a Little, set up by his we urged people to donate funds to help him get a Diploma and Bachelors degree in Sports and Exercise Science.So far the -year-old has £so far thanks to his we Waiora Tareha. Cent posted a picture of Puk said: What the f... is really going on man. I wonder why he cant get a job His post gained more than , likes from his .million followers.He was with the street gang for more than a decade, according to New Zealand Herald.Speaking to Hawkes Bay Today in New Zealand, Puk said:  Ive proved to be an inspiration for other mobsters throughout the country.“Since they have read about my lestyle change on Facebook many have been in touch asking about my fitness programs so they can follow them.He added: I know it will be hard to get a job with my tatts. I will always be a mobster but its important to show we can have better lestyles.I want to bring some of the others on board this better lestyle.Kireka spoke with Hawke’s Bay Today sports reporter Shane Hurndell, after the latter heard a spectator on the sideline commenting: “What’s that mobster doing on the field… he’s giving our code a bad look”.He told Hurndell that he had shed kg thanks to his rugby coach encouraging him to embark upon a -month-long fitness programme.This was despite him playing very little sport while at school.Kireka made his first court appearance at the age of , but “hasn’t been back since ”.The ex-lag told Hurndell he’d been “drug-free for the last four years” after kicking a meth addiction while last caged – one of two stints in prison.Aiming to become “healthy, look and feel good,” Kireka said he realised it would be tough getting employment as the lower part of his face is emblazoned with the word “Notorious” in the gang’s red and black colours.

title: noel gallagher brexit liberal elite
story: Talented bloke, decent songwriter and usually spoke a bit of sense. He’s just done so again.People who want a second vote on Brexit should go and live in North Korea, he said. Meaning that they had no time for democracy.Gallagher — like almost every bloody pop musician — backed Remain in the ­referendum. But he said: “There’s only one f***ing thing worse than a fool who voted for Brexit. That’s the rise of the c***s trying to get the vote overturned.”His message, then, to the relentlessly moaning Remainers who have tried every trick in the book to get that democratic decision overturned is: Don’t look back in anger — get on with your lives and let Brexit happen.As we decided it must.And here’s the thing. I suspect most Remainers think exactly the same. The people I know who voted Remain were saddened by the referendum result and they wished we’d all voted dferently.But they all believe that the vote must be upheld. And there should not be a second vote.And when I talk to them, they don’t call me a Nazi or a fascist for voting Leave.They don’t suggest I’m too thick to be allowed to vote or that I hate all ­foreigners.They just agree to dfer on that simple issue of in or out, and there’s no bad ­feeling at all.This is the thing. The politicians and commentators insist Brexit has ­brutally ided the nation. That the wounds will take a long time to heal. That we’re all at each other’s throats. The .million versus the .million.It’s not so at all. The only real ide is between the four or five million Remain voters who simply won’t have it — and the rest of the country.A lot has been written about the people who voted Leave — most of it codswallop.“It was just the poor and the left-behind, the uneducated and the ­xenophobes.”The statistics simply don’t bear that out.People of all walks of le, all levels of education, all ages and all ­backgrounds voted Leave.This is not, however, true of that hardcore of Remainers, between a quarter and a third of that million, who demand we run the vote again.They are insulated from the normal world. When they say they don’t know anyone who voted Leave, they’re telling the truth.They work in professions where ­virtually nobody voted Leave.In our ­universities , in schools , and among luvviesand scientists .And the BBC — I don’t have figures for the BBC but I would guess it’s close to  per cent for Remain.This is the real ide. Between a ­liberal middle-class elite who simply do not understand the hopes and aspirations of the rest of us. And react with absolute fury when they don’t get their own way.When Brexit is over, one way or another, that liberal elite will still be with us, utterly out of touch with the rest of the country.That’s the ide that matters today. A small minority determined to inflict their liberal policies upon the rest of us.THE BBC shoved an imam from Gloucester on to its Tory leadership debate programme and has now had to apologise.Abdullah Patel asked questions of the candidates about anti-Muslim bigotry in their party. Turns out he’s been accused of plenty of bigotry himself.A whole bunch of social media posts from Patel attacking Israel and praising Corbyn were uncovered. There were “Zionists” hiding behind the Holocaust, a suggestion that Israel should be transported to the centre of the US and so on. The usual stuff.None of it surprised me – and he’s not alone in pushing this view. Is it any wonder anti-semitism is now so entrenched in the Labour Party, and in our country Bob lived in Zimbabwe. Bob was standing in the middle of a road at night when a car hit him.The car cartwheeled, killing both of the people in it. They were rhino-horn smugglers – scumbags who kill rhinos so the valuable horns can be sold in powder form to sad Chinese men who can’t get a stfy.Anyway, Bob’s now dead. But his le was not given in vain.Thank you, Bob.THE latest social media trend is the bubble-tea selfie. Japanese girls take photos of themselves with a carton of the sugary drink nestled between their baps.Nope, I don’t know why.The craze is spreading west, too.People have been seen doing it in Thailand and Vietnam.Will it reach here Well, it’s got to navigate its way through Pakistan, Iran and Saudi Arabia – so I wouldn’t bet on it.THE Breakthrough Listen Project was a massive scheme using millions of computers.It was dedicated to finding intelligent extra-terrestrial le. It has found . . . nothing. Just light year after light year of utter silence.I think it’s time we accustomed ourselves to the fact there’s nothing out there and we’re all alone. The rest of the universe is cold, silent and devoid of intelligent le. Just like Canada.IT’S a shame to see Rory Stewart crashing out of the Conservative leadership race.Not because I agree with him about anything – I don’t. I’d just thought it was high time we had a PM whose real Christian name is Roderick.If people called Roderick ran the country we wouldn’t be in the mess we are now.Sure, Mr Stewart doesn’t use “Roderick”.He’s shortened it to “Rory” in order to sound more dashing and maybe a bit Celtic. Big mistake.Be proud of your given Christian name, Roderick Stewart. It means great ruler. Rory, I think, just means drunk Glaswegian eating a pie.THE bigger and richer charities get, the less likely they are to do the job they were set up to do. The RSPB is a case in point.It’s very rich indeed, with mugs like me paying for its upkeep each month.Incredibly, this organisation has flogged part of a crucial nature reserve near Middlesbrough – so a huge power station can be built on it. What possible right do they have to do that The RSPB says the Saltholme reserve is not one of high ecological signicance. But it was home to some of the UK’s most endangered birds. Not for much longer. At least the RSPB made a fast buck.HAVE you seen Joe Hart’s new tattoo  Christ help us all.It looks like half his torso has been draped in a torn bin liner.Joe doesn’t care what other people think of it – fair enough.But remembering his performances in goal for England, I wondera dferent sort of tattoo might have been more helpful. On one wrist the words: “Stand in the centre of the goal when facing a free kick, you idiot.” And on the other: “Have a go at catching the ball from time to time.”THE oldest woman in Europe has died at the age of .Italian Giuseppina Robucci credited her long, long le to avoiding alcohol.A week ago, however, the oldest woman in the UK died. Grace Jones was  when she popped her clogs, and put her longevity down to regular glasses of whisky.Hmmm. I think I’ll forfeit that extra four years and stick to Grace’s recipe.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: facebook digital currency libra ross clark
story: Now Mark Zuckerberg’s leviathan wants to democratise banking by launching a digital currency for us all, but particularly those without a bank account.Libra will be launched next year in association with  other companies including Uber, Spoty, Mastercard, eBay and Vodafone.Facebook claims Libra will make it easier, cheaper and more secure to pay for things via the internet ­compared with bank cards or other forms of payment.Libra can be sent to other users “as easily and instantly as a text message”. It will be a shiny new global currency for the st Century, taking on the dollar and the Pound.But I’m not fooled. I think we all know what Facebook is really up to.This is yet another way to harvest data about our financial habits which it can then use for targeted marketing. Critics are already calling it the “most invasive and dangerous form of surveillance ever designed”.Collecting and exploiting information about us is, after all, the whole reason for the company’s existence.Years ago it was basic stuff, like quizzes asking, “What kind of personality type are you ”Fill that in and you are practically begging to be ­targeted in marketing and ­political campaigns. But handing over our spending details is quite another matter.This may be spun as ­connecting the world and ­revolutionising payments but it is really all about tapping the modern-day version of oil — the wells of data.Facebook already knows who you are. Accept Libra and it will know what you are buying, who you’re paying and how much you have.Will it be regulated by the UK Financial Conduct Authority, as banks are in this country  Certainly, the company has not shown much desire for regulation so far — of which more later.But what do we know about how trustworthy, secure or morally sound this would-be money broker is The Cambridge Analytica scandal, where data from million users was shared with political consultants, led to a fine of £, by ­Britain’s Information ­Commissioner’s Office.Last September the company admitted that data from million of its users had leaked due to a security flaw.In  it failed to stop the live broadcast of the torture of a disabled man in Chicago. It has also refused to take down neo-Nazi content.Facebook is under criminal investigation by US prosecutors who are looking into data-sharing deals with, among other, Amazon and Apple. It has been caught out farming data from apps whose users might have been unaware they were feeding information to Facebook.The company was found to be harvesting the dates of female users’ periods via an app which tracked ovulation.Facebook has also been accused of doing little to protect ­vulnerable children from ­promotions of self-harm. British father Ian Russell has directly linked Facebook-owned Instagram to the suicide of his -year-old daughter, Molly.Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg refused to attend the UK ­Parliament’s committee on ­disinformation and “fake news” last year, amid concern the social media giant is ­positioning itself as a news publisher but without ­compliance with any of the regulation or laws governing traditional journalism.The  has been blamed for spreading hatred. In March this year an ­Australian white supremacist live-streamed on Facebook his massacre of  people at two New Zealand mosques.It has further been accused of putting IS terrorists in touch with each other via its “suggested friends” application.When challenged as to why it does not do more to tackle ­terrorism, it falls back on the explanation that it does not have the technology to watch what its .billion users are doing all the time.Yet somehow that does not seem to stop it farming commercially valuable data from our accounts.The same will no doubt turn out to be true about Libra. This week French finance ­minister Bruno Le Maire warned that the cryptocurrency would inevitably be used by terrorists and criminals to sht money around undetected.When it happens, Facebook will no doubt shrug its corporate shoulders once more and say it is powerless to stop it.In theory, the very complex nature of cryptocurrencies means that it should be near impossible for anyone to steal our money.But we have all heard the horror stories. The best-known cryptocurrency, ­Bitcoin, ­at first soared in value, ­making millions for people who latched on to it early. But  months ago it crashed.Of course, most of us like to shop on the internet — and e-commerce is only likely to grow in the coming years.But most of us do it with our bank cards or direct from accounts which hold our money in a ­currency which is backed by the central bank of a First World country.This means we can be ­reasonably sure the currency won’t ­suddenly disappear or become valueless. It is quite another matter doing business in a currency that is backed by internet firms.How can we be sure that Facebook will still be around in a few years’ time Of course, banks sometimes go bust, but at least we have some protection in the form of the Government’s financial services compensation scheme which will refund up to £, of savings in the event of a failure.Facebook claims Libra will be backed by an independent foundation in Switzerland and will be free from the kind of speculation that drove the value of Bitcoin, because its value will be linked to a basket of currencies.But I’m sorry, I’m just not buying it. I’m sticking with sterling when I do my online shopping.It might not be very exciting but I feel confident it will still be around well when Libra, and Facebook, have long ago ­disappeared. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: butcher animal rights extremists
story: Nick Rapps believes the sick message left in an A-board was linked to a protest in nearby Bristol earlier in the day.The Vegan Society said it did not support insults, and encouraged vegans to share a peaceful message.Mr Rapps said he was smiling when the photo was taken because,they upset me and I get cross then theyve won.Mr Rapps said: Theres far worse places to protest than a farm shop which sells free range organic meat, instead of intensively-farmed supermarket stuff.Im aware theres a subculture of vegan protesters but nobody deserves to have signs like that outside their shop.He added: I did find it funny - one side calling me a murderer and the other side saying they wanted my family to die. I dont want to belittle anybody but it wont deter me.This protest does make me sympathise with the overall vegan community, because its not doing them any favours and many of them want to promote a peaceful existence.The Vegan Society said veganism is based on kindness and compassion, and that any extremists are not representative of the movement.It added: As much as we sympathise with the activists who allegedly put up the signs, we do not consider this approach to be an effective way to promote veganism as an ethics-driven lestyle. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may secretive tory leadership vote
story: The PM again yesterday refused to reveal who she backed after casting her vote in the third knock out ballot to pick a new Tory leader.Her spokesman revealed: “When she says she hasn’t told anyone who she’s voting for, I can confirm that includes her husband”.The Premier’s tight-lipped stance even surprised her aides, as financial adviser Philip May is also her closest political advisor.Mrs May was quizzed about who she backed on leaving the Commons voting room yesterday afternoon.She wagged her finger at reporters as she said: “I told you yesterday, none of your business.”But the PM will today face a dficult dilemma on what to do when she leaves Westminster for an EU summit in Brussels at lunchtime.The second of the two final ballots in the contest only opens at .pm, meaning she would have to trust an MP with her choice, and to keep it secret,she wants to vote by proxy.Mrs May’s spokesman refused to say what she will do last night, adding only: “She wants to participate in the process”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: foreign aid budget clueless spending watchdog
story: A probe by the National Audit Office concluded the Government “does not know” whether the bloated budget is delivering value for money because of its decision to ide the money between dferent departments.The proportion of the budget spent by the Department for International Development has fallen from  per cent to  per cent over the last three years, while spending by other departments such as the Foreign Office, Home Office, Business, Health and Education departments has in some cases more than trebled.Spending by non-Dfid departments has led to more aid money going to middle-income countries, the NAO said.This change has endangered the Government’s aim of reducing poverty in the world’s poorest countries.In a separate report published today the aid spending watchdog has given amber red warnings to eight of  current UK Aid projects, meaning there are signicant concerns.These included projects that are tackling international tax evasion and another on supporting marginalised girls abroad.The NAO report also warned that a chaotic Brexit could mean Dfid having to spend the £. billion money it usually spends through the EU in a very short period of time in order to meet the annual . per cent target.This money would have to be spent in a matter of months and would unlikely to deliver value for money, the report warned.The NAO blasted the Treasury for failing to assess whether this approach had delivered value for money for taxpayers.As a result, no one was tracking whether the £ billion budget was being spent properly, the study concluded.Gareth Davies, the head of the NAO, said: “The ODA spending target has been successfully met for the past five years. It is however unclear whether government is achieving its objectives in the  UK Aid Strategy.“Government does not know whether giving responsibility for spending ODA to a larger number of departments has had the impact it intended. And its progress in improving the transparency of spending has been slow.“While there is good evidence that many aid programmes are securing an impact inidually, government does not know whether all parts of ODA, taken together, are securing value for money.”The reports piled pressure on Aid Secretary and Tory leadership candidate Rory Stewart.Responding to the reports he said last night: “The NAO report raises questions about how aid is spent across government.“So I will be working closely with my colleagues in other aid-spending departments to support them and ensure they benefit from DfID’s expertise. I am determined that together we make the changes required.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast met office sunshine
story: Forecasters said there would be sunny spells for most of England and Wales, with the chance of an odd shower.But the Met Office warned there is still the chance of isolated thunderstorms in Scotland.“The heaviest showers will be across Scotland, with the risk of isolated thunderstorms,” a Met Office spokesman said.“The showers will fade across much of northern England and Wales during the afternoon, but it will be breezy.”Temperatures appear as though they will peak at around C in Norwich and C in London.It comes after Britain has been battered by three days of thunderstorms and flooding.Around  people were evacuated after “unprecedented” downpours saw double the monthly rainfall in just three days at Wainfleet, Lincs.Rescue workers in the flood-hit town pumped out enough water to fill  Olympic swimming pools yesterday.Royal Ascot got off to a scorching start yesterday before rain descended and put a dampener on the celebrations.Bookmaker Coral has cut the odds into -on this year’s Royal Ascot being the wettest on record.The firm is offering - that this month end as the wettest ever June in the UK, while looking further ahead, it is - for rain to fall on every day of Wimbledon this year.“It’s going to be a very damp start to Royal Ascot this year which is going to make it a challenge for those looking to impress on the fashion front.“With so much rain forecast to fall, we have the slashed the odds on this being the wettest ever staging of the Royal meeting,” said Coral’s John Hill.Glastonbury Festival - which starts next week - risks mud and more showers after mm of rain soaked Somerset this month.And Wimbledon, which runs from July -, faces being plagued by rain breaks, according to John Hammond of Weathertrending.

title: dont let emma be pm years and years
story: And I know I wasn’t the only one thinking: “Yes, the real Emma Thompson becoming Prime Minister.” She’d empty the joint. It’d be Britain the “do-as-I-say-not-as-I-do” years.An horric thought that certainly added a bit of perspective to the penultimate episode of Years And Years, which was written by Doctor Who’s Russell T Davies in a fit of anti-Brexit Trump rage, thereby guaranteeing it would age about as well as Neil “Razor” Ruddock.The blasé assumption that went with it was that this series would be one of ’s big hits, so I won’t pretend the fact it’s died like the proverbial flea in a Russian’s beard hasn’t given me a lot of pleasure.It will have been a huge shock, though, to the BBC because, on the face of things, it was a bold and imaginative idea to travel ten years into the future with “an ordinary, everyday” family like the Lyons.Or it was up to the point when it became clear they were the sort of “ordinary, everyday” family who lived in a million-pound mansion and had more ticked boxes than Stephen Hawking’s homework.They were mixed race, naturally. One daughter was a lesbian left-wing activist, another was in a wheelchair, there was a gay son, with a refugee boyfriend, a cross-dressing nephew and niece who was “trans-human” and could take photos by blinking her eyes. All of them were bloody insufferable.The plot didn’t offer a lot of joy or surprises either, as it began with Donald Trump starting a nuclear war. An idea that secretly thrills all thosereaders who long to shout: “I TOLD YOU SO.”Armageddon quickly fizzled out, though, and was replaced by the melting of the North Pole, bananas becoming extinct, poor people being banned from London’s Kensington, Biblical downpours of rain and the Ukraine causing a refugee crisis when its Christian regime started arresting homosexuals, as Christian regimes so often don’t.Ben Shephard: “What is the fth letter of the alphabet ” Faith: “F.”And Love Island, Tommy: “What year did World War One start ” Molly-Mae: “.”Cheerful and brave, it most certainly wasn’t. The BBC doesn’t get a real buzz, though, unless it’s sticking it to the mother country.  So, on last week’s episode, Viv Rook became PM and immediately started planning genocide on asylum seekers. It’s not an original drama idea, obviously.Dennis Potter did the groundwork for Davies in Brimstone  Treacle, over  years ago. On Years And Years, however, plot twists come with a gear-crunching speech or a history lesson, spelled out here by the Thompson character.The thing about giving history lessons, though, is you’ve got to get them right. Years And Years didn’t.Simple Googling would’ve told the BBC concentration camps were actually a Spanish invention, during the Cuban wars of independence, and forced labour dates back centuries.I suspect they didn’t bother because the BBC and Russell T Davies are both so full of self-loathing they want to believe the worst things they hear about their own country.If you didn’t pick up that contempt for the audience from Years And Years last week, you certainly will have got a sense of it from the fact the BBC decided to land .million people over the age of  with a £. bill for the licence.It’s unlikely anyone would volunteer to pay that sort of money to endure the Years And Years lecture, no matter what it conjures up in tonight’s finale.Though how the hell it ever survived to , under the current management, will be the real mystery for most viewers.Shelley Kerr: “The one thing we want to do is win or get a draw.”Claire Rafferty: “England need more of the same but dferent.”Rachel Brown-Finnis: “Phil Neville is the female version of Gareth Southgate.” He is .LONG, cold evenings in a Highland yurt, staring at the same ruddy animals year after year, can lead presenters down all sorts of weird television cul-de-sacs.Take, for instance, Springwatch’s Michaela Strachan who, after a couple of weeks huddled in the Cairngorms, on BBC, suddenly piped up with some hot news about: “Starling testicles.”Yes. Starling testicles, which are a bit like Aston Villa, apparently.  Timid, puny little things in the winter but quite magnicent come the spring.A fact that led Michaela to wonderviewers could “imagine flying round with testicles the size of a bean ”  I could, and it quite took the thrill out of my new superpower, I can tell you.If that wasn’t a vivid enough image for you, though, co-host Chris Packham was on hand with a starling testicle-size graph and a prop, to tell her thathuman testicles swelled to the same scale, they’d be the size of basketballs.“And that’s quite a thing to get your head around, isn’t it ”I’ll take your word for it, Michaela.HAVING gone absolutely nowhere for over a week, Love Island was transformed on Wednesday by the arrival of a heat-seeking missile in human form. She’s Maura Higgins, an Irish “ring girl”. A description you can interpret pretty much any way you like.Because she may look like one of The Corrs, but Maura has a gob on her like Father Jack and, within five minutes of meeting Molly-Mae’s partner Tommy, was telling anyone who’d listen: “I swear to God, the things I’d do to that man. ‘Oh Tommy, Tommy, Tommy’. I can imagine screaming his name already.”That was just for starters, though.By Thursday, Maura was announcing her intention to “wrap my legs round his head”, which Tommy said was “doing a -degree turn”, without any danger of cutting off the blood supply to his brain. And on Friday she told all the other girls Tommy was giving her “fanny flutters”, who I think I once backed to win the  Guineas.Tommy’s now wearing the same haunted expression as a male praying mantis just before his head’s removed during the mating process, but by far the best thing about Maura’s arrival in the villa has been her verdict on herself. “I’m a girl’s girl.” RemarkableThe naive but still widespread belief Madonna will one day give a good interview. Channel  imagining it was doing us some sort of favour by replacing the brilliant Gogglebox regulars with witless minor celebrities.And The One Show’s Matt Baker telling Clare Balding that women’s football is: “Much better than the men’s game.”Suggesting Matt Baker’s either never seen a game of football in his le or he’s a disingenuous creep who’ll say absolutely anything he thinks will help him grovel his way up the BBC career ladder. Pitul behaviour.ITV’S England v Soccer Aid XI match was more entertaining and funnier than expected, largely thanks to Mark Wright’s penalty miss and Ant Middleton’s above-the-knee sock arrangement, which I think was meant to give him the graceful air of Thierry Henry, but actually just looked more like Lord Percy from Blackadder II was playing at right back.So why then did commentator Clive Tyldesley choose to cheapen the occasion by questioning Piers Morgan’s ethnic credentials for managing the victorious World XI, when tests have already confirmed he’s so authentically Irish  per cent of his DNA can be traced directly to Mayo, the other quarter to chips Paddy McGuinness’ and Freddie Flintoff’s first Top Gear already looking like a vast improvement on all the other post-Clarkson versions.BBC’s landmark Thatcher: A Very British Revolution series. And Harry Hill’s savage Alien Fun Capsule introductions: “Bill Roache, you’ve appeared in so many . . . you haven’t actually, have you.”THIS week’s winner is Curtis Pritchard, from Love Island, and Elvis Cridlington, from Fireman Sam.ITV continuity: “You can catch up with the brilliant and witty new drama Wild Bill on the ITV Hub.”And Springwatch, Chris Packham: “You might think Paul Gascoigne’s goal against Scotland in  was spectacularly beautul.” Yeah, and I might not, badger-bothering BBC a**e.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour peer try force government
story: NewsLabour Peer to try and force Government to fund TV licences for the over-s againThe  stitch-up ultimately led to last week’s decision by the BBC to means-test the leline so only those on Pension Credit will be eligibleShareByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  JUN NewsLord George Foulkes is bringing a private members bill "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Labour peer will try and force the Government to take back responsibility for funding free TV licences for the over-s. Lord George Foulkes will table a Private Member’s Bill on Thursday aimed at repealing the provision which switched the burden onto the BBC. The  stitch-up ultimately led to last week’s decision by the Corporation to means-test the leline so only over-s on Pension Credit will be eligible. It came despite the Conservatives promising at the  election to preserve the benefit for the duration of this Parliament, due to run until . An estimated . million OAPS face being stripped of free licences, worth £. a year, under the plan.    Only around . million households will be eligible under the new scheme. Speaking exclusively to the Mirror, Lord Foulkes said: “TV is vital for older people living alone and . million, including many struggling to survive on the basic pension, now face the loss the of their free TV licence. “This is a social welfare issue and one that the Conservatives promised in their manesto to protect for the letime of this Parliament. “That responsibility cannot be passed from the Government to the BBC. “My Bill will transfer the responsibility back to the Government, thereby enabling them to keep their election promise to maintain these free TV licences.” Currently all households with someone aged  or over are entitled to a free licence. But the universal benefit was doomed when the Tories and BBC agreed a deal in  for the corporation to take on the burden of funding the licences. Yet just two years later, the Conservatives pledged in their election manesto to protect the benefit until .    BBC Director-General Lord Tony Hall blamed Tory austerity for the move, which would have lumped the Corporation with a £million annual bill to maintain the concession. “I remember the conversation with the then Secretary of State very, very clearly…- this was going to happen come what may,” he told peers this week. “We took on this policy and it was made quite clear ... the policy would come to us and we would have to consult on it, and that is exactly what we have done.” Lord Foulkes, an MP for  years, a former Scotland Minister and a former director of Age Concern Scotland, hopes the plan will receive wide support across Parliament and force a U-turn by the Tories. The Mirror is campaigning to save the leline, with more than , readers backing the battle by completing coupons in the paper.Royle Family actor Ricky Tomlinson and former Labour Prime Minister Gordon Brown have supported the fight.More than , people have signed Age UK’s Switched Off petition calling for the licences to be preserved and the Government to take back responsibility.  Age UK charity director Caroline Abrahams said “We congratulate Lord Foulkes for bringing forward this Private Member’s Bill and very much hope that other Parliamentarians will support it.    “The free TV licence means so much to millions of older people and we strongly agree with him that this Conservative Government should stand by their manesto commitment and provide the funds so these free licences can continue.” Hundreds of protesters are expected to join demonstrations outside local BBC offices tomorrow hitting out at the curb. The rallies are organised by the National Pensioners Convention, whose general secretary Jan Shortt: “The buck really stops with the Government. “The Conservatives promised to keep the concession but have done everything to undermine it. “It’s not the job of the broadcaster to administer or fund part of our wider welfare policy, it’s the Government’s.” Bectu broadcasting union head Philippa Childs said: “The Government has put the BBC in an invidious position since its  manesto U-turn and we welcome any efforts by Lord George Foulkes to get this decision reversed in Westminster. “We have consistently said, on behalf of our members working at the BBC, that the over-s licence is a welfare benefit and the Government’s responsibility to pay and they should not have passed the buck.”

The mum-of-three said her diagnosis has helped her make sense of why she has struggled with certain things in le.She told HullLive : My diagnosis certainly made all my leaposs struggles make sense.   As a child I always struggled with friendships, never liked busy places and have a lot of sensory issues, very similar to Sadie, but I had no support and grew up learning to manage. I failed at a lot of things and learnt to avoid the things that overwhelmed me. A lot of Sadieaposs quirks were very similar to mine and the more research I did, the more I questioned my own le and struggles. During Sadieaposs private assessment, the paediatrician make a few remarks about how itaposs often genetic and she noticed similarities in me while I was there all day. Ms Coulson regrets not being diagnosed with Autism sooner. She said: I wish I had been diagnosed sooner. I spent most of my le struggling and not knowing why, I struggled with feeling weird and dferent and the odd one out. Sadie was so delighted when I was diagnosed, she said we were a team. People always say a diagnosis is a label. I say itaposs a not a label, its your self-identity and self-confidence and it allows you to learn your strengths and to no longer focus on the negatives.    If I had known itaposs because I was autistic, I could have become more confident with who I was as a person. Now Iaposm diagnosed, I have an identity, I am far more confident about who I am, and I am able to teach Sadie how to be happy with herself and never excuse her traits as they are a part of her. Ms Coulson said having autism helps her to help Sadie but said that she is unable to help assist in some circumstances. She said: Itaposs amazing being able to support her by using my experiences and points of view, but it can be very dficult bringing up an autistic child when you are also autistic, no autistic person is the same. Me and Sadie are like chalk and cheese, our sensory dficulties are almost opposite. Sadie loves to be tactile, and I hate being touched. But I allow her to get the physical contact she needs, because at the end of the day, sheaposs my daughter. Ms Coulson said she has learned to tolerate the things that overwhelm her. She said: I bottle it all up all day and Iaposm able to shut myself down to recover. Sadie has meltdowns, sheaposs too young to be able to control and manage her emotions.  I however, have shutdowns. Thataposs where I just need to be alone and quiet. I am emotionally and physically unable to interact because I have built up being overwhelmed all say dealing with Sadie, my other children, being a local dyspraxia coordinator, paperwork and tribunals for Sadieaposs support. Everything is a constant battle. Itaposs really hard work. But I am very open now about being autistic - mainly in the hope Sadie sees that I am confident about it so she can become anything she wants. I am a nursery nurse, but I failed at university when I wanted to be a teacher, because I socially couldnapost cope. That makes me sad. Sadie wants to be a zoo vet, she is obsessed with reptiles as am I, and I want her to believe she can achieve anything. Ms Coulson said Sadie understands a lot about autism. When she was younger she would cry herself to sleep, asking aposwhy am I dferent apos - but now she knows why. She said: When she got formally diagnosed she was happy and singing and dancing and making a song up in the garden singing aposI am autistic and I love it.apos Itaposs part of her and her self-identity so it will help her in the future to understand herself.

story: NewsopinionNow Thats What I Call NOT Music...Eight music styles or artists that should be bannedIn the wake of Danny Boyle’s movie Yesterday, we asked our brilliant writers which band, pop star or musical style they would most like to say Hello Goodbye to for goodShareCommentsByMirror:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsopinionHimesh Patel stars in Yesterday "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn Richard Curtis and Danny Boyle’s movie Yesterday, Jackfinds himself in a world without the Beatles’ music.Giving that concept a twist , we asked our brilliant writers which band, pop star or musical style they would most like to say Hello Goodbyeto for good.Comedy Songs I hate comedy songs with a passion. I don’t just mean novelty hits by the likes of Mr Blobby, or Crazy Frog, below. I’m talking about Spitting Image, Monty Python, Victoria Wood and The Goodies among others.  I know some people consider these to be classic songs. I also know it is a skill that not many artists can master. But as far as I’m concerned, when you’ve heard a comedy song once you’ve heard it enough. This has developed into an irrational hatred. Unfortunately, I’ve told so many people about it I know Always Look on the Bright Side of Le will be played at my funeral. Still, at least I won’t hear it.By Ian HylandGary Barlow He wrote a million beige love songs and put up with a thousand punchlines from Robbie Williams instead of chinning him. He organised a fawning Jubilee concert for the Queen and was given an OBE which clearly stood for “Outrageously Brown-nosing Elizabeth” after which Prince Charles called him a National Treasure.  But it transpired he was a Keeper Of The National Treasure as he wasn’t paying all of his taxes. Worse, he tried to win the youth vote for the Tories by saying “There’s no one more with-it than David Cameron.” As Danny Dyer would say: “what an effing Take That.”By Brian ReadeAdam Faith Music would have been better of without Terence Nelhams-Wright, better known to his fans – including my teenage girlfriend – as Adam Faith.  His love-sick melodies were all the rage from the early sixties when he recorded Poor Meand Someone Else’s Baby . He rivalled Clf Richard in popularity, competing for the most sugary lyrics with songs like “I Love You, You Love Me” . His most embarrassing single was “Lonely Pup In A Christmas Shop” Faith died spectacularly aged  of a heart attack in bed with his young mistress. Sadly, his narcissistic, whining style is back in fashion.By Paul RoutledgeChris De Burgh Chris de bloody Burgh ruined my teenage years.  It was the era of punk and new wave, rebellion in the air with another world possible. Mates pogoed to exciting bands such as the Sex Pistols, Stranglers, Clash and Jam. Yours truly queued at Newcastle City Hall’s stage door to meet an unfashionable chanteur. Looking back it was inexplicable madness yet I liked folk music and in my defence it was before Lady in Red. I’ve kept de Burgh’s first four albums on their scratchy plastic. £ each or a fiver for the lot. Expunge him from history and I could’ve been another mutinous teen instead of a blushing ftysomething.By Kevin MaguireHeavy Metal Aggressive, loud and with no discernible melody, I absolutely cannot stand heavy metal. I’m sure that lovers of this baffling genre would point out where I’m wrong, but I just don’t get it.  With screeching guitars, thrashing drums and usually a terrying-looking man in need of a wash shrieking down a microphone, apparently in a really bad mood, is this meant to be music  It all sounds the same! A fan of Iron Maiden and Def Leppard  Well aren’t you just super cool. I’m well aware that my taste for Take That, musicals and a rousing power ballad doesn’t give me any musical credibility - but I’ll keep my jazz hands over a headache any day.By Sara WallisAnyone Can Fall in Love I’ve never been a fan of the TV theme tune so popular that someone, somewhere believes it has to be turned into a pop song.  There are lots of examples but the one I still have nightmares about is the EastEnder’s aberration, Anyone Can Fall In Love. Decent, catchy and a soap opera staple. What it didn’t need was for Anita Dobson to perform it on Top Of The Pops, right. I still can’t believe it reached number four in the charts in . Music history would survive just fine without the contribution of that track andothers like it.By Darren LewisJedward I’ve interviewed some true musical legends – Ringo Starr, Tom Jones, Lionel Richie and Gary Barlow .  But my brush with the spiky-mopped X Factor stars was so bizarre it still makes my hair stand on end thinking about it. I was locked in a small office with the Grimes twins as scores of adoring fans screamed outside and the boys serenaded them out of the window. Jedward were so high on sugary drinks they were bouncing off the walls and the hour-long interview was a farce. I failed to get even one coherent quote out of them and my boss wasn’t happy. So I would like to erase Jedward from pop history purely for putting me Under Pressure. It wasn’t nice, baby.By Rachael BletchlyI Wish It Could Be Christmas Every Day Wizzard’s I Wish It Could Be Christmas Every Day needs to be wiped off the face off the earth.

story: NewsSchool slammed for asking pupils to vote for best looking childHugh Christie School, in Tonbridge, Kent, has apologised for sending out an "inappropriate" form to Year  pupilsShareCommentsByVicky Castle:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsA form given to Year  pupils has sparked outrage "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA school which encouraged pupils to vote for the best looking child has apologised after a backlash from parents. Hugh Christie School, in Tonbridge, Kent, came under fire after a form was given to Year  students asking them to select their most attractive classmates.A furious aunt shared a picture of it on Twitter , branding it shocking, Kent Live reports .Lucy Hall wrote: My nephews school just sent them home with this - school is hard enough when you are  to create awards over best looking boy and girl. Shocking. Hugh Christie School why would you let this happen  Parents are appalled by this.    The celebration assembly awards nominations form asked pupils to vote for other pupils in a number of categories before the end of year assembly. The  and -year-olds were asked to nominate classmates for awards including aposbest looking maleapos, aposbest looking femaleapos, aposbiggest poserapos and aposbest coupleapos. But the school has backtracked and told pupils to disregard the form. In a tweet responding to the outrage, Huge Christie School wrote: We will inform students to disregard the form. The member of staff responsible has been spoken to.    We totally agree this was inappropriate and apologise unreservedly for any offence caused to our students and parents. But the list has sparked outrage among parents who slammed the superficial catagories. Cha Groome said: That’s horrendous! Victoria Jay added: Why not have things like: kindest pupil, most enthusiastic, most sporty, best jokes, tries the best, most helpful, most friendly, most likely to invent something  be a millionaire change the world be PM. Sure it was well meant, but asking kids to vote on looks and biggest poser and who is stroppiest reinforces belief that your looks matter most. On website the founder’s values: outstanding character, integrity  courage. A good place to start. Chrissa added: Absolutely disgraceful. How about we give this school the award for “How to ruin a cohort’s mental health and self worth” - they are worthy of that!

title: treatment frail six stone man
story: NewsDWP treatment of frail six-stone man deemed fit to find work followed policyStephen Smith, , from Liverpool died in April was repeatedly and incorrectly turned down for benefitsShareCommentsByLiam ThorpAmber Hicks:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsStephen could barely walk before he died"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe treatment of a six-stone man deemed fit to find work by the DWP despite barely being able to walk before he died aposfollowed policy,apos according to an investigation.Images of Stephen Smithaposs skeletal frame shocked the nation when they were published earlier this year.The fragile -year-old was forced to get a pass to leave hospital to fight the Department for Work and Pensionapossdecision to axe his disability benefits. He was also repeatedly and incorrectly turned down for benefits while suffering with a number of serious illnesses before his death in April, reports the Liverpool Echo.The DWP had ruled the Liverpudlian could work and ordered him to sign on for Job Seekeraposs Allowance and head to the job centre once a week to prove he was looking for work.    But the tribunal ruled in favour of Mr Smith after a judge saw he could barely walk down the road and the DWP were made to pay him £, in back pay. Sadly, he never had the chance to use it - and the money was used to pay for his funeral. Now an investigation into the treatment of Mr Smith has shockingly found that the DWP aposfollowed policyapos. It comes after there were widespread calls for an independent inquiry into his treatment, including from Birkenhead MP and Work and Pensions Committee chair Frank Field.    He wrote to Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd who would not grant a full inquiry - instead only ordering an internal DWP review. The results of that review have now been revealed. Writing to Mr Field, Ms Rudd states: This review has now concluded and shows that whilst the policy guidance was followed in Mr Smithaposs case, there were crucial safeguarding opportunities which were missed by the Department. The review has identied areas where we need to change our policy and we will be implementing these changes to ensure our most vulnerable claimants are protected.    The letter states that the changes will include:- Identying other trigger points for information sharing between lines to improve, join up and provide more holistic support -Improving awareness across benefit lines of how new awards to or changes in benefit entitlement can materially affect other benefits in payment or under appeal - and encouraging or requiring staff to look for an act on these these links. - Identying the opportunities to embed these recommendations effectively and quickly across multiple customer journeysMs Rudd wrote: The Department will be working at pace to ensure that these are embedded and that vulnerable claimants are receiving the best possible support from the Department. I am adamant that we will learn important lessons from this tragic case and make changes to protect people like Mr Smith in future.    Mr Field was seriously unimpressed with the lack of humanity and abundance of jargon in a response about the death of a man so clearly failed by the system. He told the ECHO: ‘This letter heavily disguises the fact that we’re talking about a man who lost his le, not a package that got lost within the DWP. It sums up much of what’s wrong with the DWP, which is apparently very short on human sympathy. What kind of policy guidance is it that fails to recognise that somebody is seriously ill and dying ’
